page.title: 07Ecology In Notgrove
page.content: In this rural part of the Cotswolds there is a rich tapestry of wild flowers and birds. The limestone favours lime loving plants and in some years, Bee Orchids and Twayblades are to be found in certain areas. Along the track of the dismantled railway and in the several coppices in the area, Hawthorn, Sycamore, Ash, Elder, Beech and Hazel trees abound, creating their own mini environment of wild life. By early September the Squirrels are already raiding the Hazel nuts. An occasional Buzzard is seen overhead. Several footpaths criss cross the area mainly following the edges of the fields and giving lovely views as far as the eye can see. Being 200 to 250 metres above sea level, the climate is bracing with a gentle breeze blowing on most summer days, turning to a chill wind in winter.
